body: The problem is, I don't have any innate or natural talent whatsoever in any subject, and almost everyone I know does for some reason. Unfortunately practice only makes what you have perfect, and I don't have much. So I'm stuck with a skill ceiling too low to be able to do much of anything. Still, at least I haven't given up like most people. But I feel alone and dumb because I don't know anybody else who isn't ultra gifted.

body: I appreciate the help but witchcraft is a deception operated by demons. Please understand that and get out while you still can. Paintings of red dragon people with horns and a pitchfork are completely misleading, they will try to appear warm and welcoming because no one is going to just announce that they're evil, if they acknowledge their evil at all. They do this because they want to be god so they can take over and control everyone. They're experts at making themselves appear goodhearted and attractive to convince people to follow them. In reality though they only care about themselves and taking advantage of people to get what they want. It doesn't matter what they have to offer, it's always a trick, and it's not worth becoming their slaves even if they give you everything you'd ever wanted. Please at least heed my warning. If you have any questions at all about this *please* ask, I'm begging you.

body: I'll just say this... some of the biggest bands of all time were people who just made creative use of their limited abilities. As a musician myself I can speak to this. I know how high my skill ceiling goes. I reach a certain point and I can play no faster. Every musician comes to this point and then learns to make creative use of what they have. Perfection is an illusion. The creative spark is what matters, and that potential is there at all skill levels.

body:
> creative

Oh yeah, I'm not the greatest in that department either. I can't even think of good titles for ruqqus posts. The most obvious solutions to problems go right over my head. And my mind can do nothing but robotically copy what others have done for me.

> Perfection is an illusion. The creative spark is what matters, and that potential is there at all skill levels.

You're clearly still at a high enough level to do that though. I'm not, nothing ever clicks with me no matter how badly I want it to. The only thing that distinguishes me from the average person is that I haven't given up yet upon finding out that I'm not cut out, so I'm a little better than them. But maybe that's not such a good thing if I have no hope of doing anything but failing miserably at even the smallest things. The problem is, I can't do what I want to do, because I'm not capable of it. But everyone else is. After years of practicing and having dreams I'm still nowhere even close to where everyone else doing the same thing *started out* with a fraction of the effort. My improvements are always extremely minor and localized to a specific procedure, and happen very slowly, meaning I'm already at my ceiling. I know I'll never make it to where I want, with anything in life, and there's not a fucking thing I can do about it.
body_html:
creative

Oh yeah, I'm not the greatest in that department either. I can't even think of good titles for ruqqus posts. The most obvious solutions to problems go right over my head. And my mind can do nothing but robotically copy what others have done for me.

Perfection is an illusion. The creative spark is what matters, and that potential is there at all skill levels.

After years of practicing and having dreams I'm still nowhere even close to where everyone else doing the same thing started out with a fraction of the effort. My improvements are always extremely minor and localized to a specific procedure, and happen very slowly, meaning I'm already at my ceiling. I know I'll never make it to where I want, with anything in life, and there's not a fucking thing I can do about it.

post.title: Anyone out there who's closer to my talent level? I feel so alone here.

body:
I am at a high enough level to do that now, but my creative output has been pretty close to the same from my starting point up to now. Adding new skills hasn't really accelerated it, only changed the shape of the outcome. Also, I still pick up new instruments now and then and have to struggle to learn. Being stuck at a starting point has a way of forcing you to be creative, though, so I don't think even that is a bad thing.

If we're talking about potential career paths it's kind of a different story, I guess. But otherwise it's completely fine to have a low skill ceiling. It doesn't matter what anyone thinks of your output. I don't even show most of my stuff to other people, and I've been working on some of my music for years in private. Once I learned to be okay with doing it just for myself, a lot of my self doubts fell away.

I hope you'll keep trying, whatever it is.
body_html:
I am at a high enough level to do that now, but my creative output has been pretty close to the same from my starting point up to now. Adding new skills hasn't really accelerated it, only changed the shape of the outcome. Also, I still pick up new instruments now and then and have to struggle to learn. Being stuck at a starting point has a way of forcing you to be creative, though, so I don't think even that is a bad thing.

If we're talking about potential career paths it's kind of a different story, I guess. But otherwise it's completely fine to have a low skill ceiling. It doesn't matter what anyone thinks of your output. I don't even show most of my stuff to other people, and I've been working on some of my music for years in private. Once I learned to be okay with doing it just for myself, a lot of my self doubts fell away.

I hope you'll keep trying, whatever it is.

> creative

Oh yeah, I'm not the greatest in that department either. I can't even think of good titles for ruqqus posts. The most obvious solutions to problems go right over my head. And my mind can do nothing but robotically copy what others have done for me.

> Perfection is an illusion. The creative spark is what matters, and that potential is there at all skill levels.

You're clearly still at a high enough level to do that though. I'm not, nothing ever clicks with me no matter how badly I want it to. The only thing that distinguishes me from the average person is that I haven't given up yet upon finding out that I'm not cut out, so I'm a little better than them. But maybe that's not such a good thing if I have no hope of doing anything but failing miserably at even the smallest things. The problem is, I can't do what I want to do, because I'm not capable of it. But everyone else is. After years of practicing and having dreams I'm still nowhere even close to where everyone else doing the same thing *started out* with a fraction of the effort. My improvements are always extremely minor and localized to a specific procedure, and happen very slowly, meaning I'm already at my ceiling. I know I'll never make it to where I want, with anything in life, and there's not a fucking thing I can do about it.
parent.body_html:
creative

Oh yeah, I'm not the greatest in that department either. I can't even think of good titles for ruqqus posts. The most obvious solutions to problems go right over my head. And my mind can do nothing but robotically copy what others have done for me.

Perfection is an illusion. The creative spark is what matters, and that potential is there at all skill levels.

You're clearly still at a high enough level to do that though. I'm not, nothing ever clicks with me no matter how badly I want it to. The only thing that distinguishes me from the average person is that I haven't given up yet upon finding out that I'm not cut out, so I'm a little better than them. But maybe that's not such a good thing if I have no hope of doing anything but failing miserably at even the smallest things. The problem is, I can't do what I want to do, because I'm not capable of it. But everyone else is. After years of practicing and having dreams I'm still nowhere even close to where everyone else doing the same thing started out with a fraction of the effort. My improvements are always extremely minor and localized to a specific procedure, and happen very slowly, meaning I'm already at my ceiling. I know I'll never make it to where I want, with anything in life, and there's not a fucking thing I can do about it.

post.body: The problem is, I don't have any innate or natural talent whatsoever in any subject, and almost everyone I know does for some reason. Unfortunately practice only makes what you have perfect, and I don't have much. So I'm stuck with a skill ceiling too low to be able to do much of anything. Still, at least I haven't given up like most people. But I feel alone and dumb because I don't know anybody else who isn't ultra gifted.
post.body_html: The problem is, I don't have any innate or natural talent whatsoever in any subject, and almost everyone I know does for some reason. Unfortunately practice only makes what you have perfect, and I don't have much. So I'm stuck with a skill ceiling too low to be able to do much of anything. Still, at least I haven't given up like most people. But I feel alone and dumb because I don't know anybody else who isn't ultra gifted.
post.title: Anyone out there who's closer to my talent level? I feel so alone here.

author.bio:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.
author.bio_html:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

body:
> my creative output has been pretty close to the same from my starting point up to now. Adding new skills hasn't really accelerated it, only changed the shape of the outcome.

Exactly, so there's no hope for it to ever change. I'll always be hopelessly dull.

> Being stuck at a starting point has a way of forcing you to be creative, though, so I don't think even that is a bad thing.

That's true for a lot of people, depending on whether they want results or challenge. I wouldn't necessarily be opposed to that myself for certain subjects. But remember I can't even come up with halfway decent titles for ruqqus posts, even when spending a half hour trying to do so. *Everyone* else can at least do that in under a minute. My creativity is almost zero. Better than *nothing* I guess, but not enough to keep things enjoyable.

> If we're talking about potential career paths it's kind of a different story, I guess. But otherwise it's completely fine to have a low skill ceiling. It doesn't matter what anyone thinks of your output. I don't even show most of my stuff to other people, and I've been working on some of my music for years in private. Once I learned to be okay with doing it just for myself, a lot of my self doubts fell away.

Ironically most people in my career path kind of fake their way through it and get good jobs without actually being any good, so I'll be fine with that. And most people are impressed with me because they just gave up entirely when they found out they weren't cut out for it. But the problem arises when I want to actually do things for myself, and I'm not good enough to be able to. I can ask other people to do it for me, but I don't like that idea. I don't want to have to rely on other people for things I'm also interested in. For one, I have to sacrifice my control over it, two I'll either have to burden someone or pay for it, and most importantly it takes all the fun and joy out of doing it myself. This is especially frustrating when everyone else I know *is* good enough to do things themselves, at least some of the things they're into, perhaps all of them.
body_html:
my creative output has been pretty close to the same from my starting point up to now. Adding new skills hasn't really accelerated it, only changed the shape of the outcome.

Exactly, so there's no hope for it to ever change. I'll always be hopelessly dull.

Being stuck at a starting point has a way of forcing you to be creative, though, so I don't think even that is a bad thing.

That's true for a lot of people, depending on whether they want results or challenge. I wouldn't necessarily be opposed to that myself for certain subjects. But remember I can't even come up with halfway decent titles for ruqqus posts, even when spending a half hour trying to do so. Everyone else can at least do that in under a minute. My creativity is almost zero. Better than nothing I guess, but not enough to keep things enjoyable.

If we're talking about potential career paths it's kind of a different story, I guess. But otherwise it's completely fine to have a low skill ceiling. It doesn't matter what anyone thinks of your output. I don't even show most of my stuff to other people, and I've been working on some of my music for years in private. Once I learned to be okay with doing it just for myself, a lot of my self doubts fell away.

Ironically most people in my career path kind of fake their way through it and get good jobs without actually being any good, so I'll be fine with that. And most people are impressed with me because they just gave up entirely when they found out they weren't cut out for it. But the problem arises when I want to actually do things for myself, and I'm not good enough to be able to. I can ask other people to do it for me, but I don't like that idea. I don't want to have to rely on other people for things I'm also interested in. For one, I have to sacrifice my control over it, two I'll either have to burden someone or pay for it, and most importantly it takes all the fun and joy out of doing it myself. This is especially frustrating when everyone else I know is good enough to do things themselves, at least some of the things they're into, perhaps all of them.

parent.body:
I am at a high enough level to do that now, but my creative output has been pretty close to the same from my starting point up to now. Adding new skills hasn't really accelerated it, only changed the shape of the outcome. Also, I still pick up new instruments now and then and have to struggle to learn. Being stuck at a starting point has a way of forcing you to be creative, though, so I don't think even that is a bad thing.

If we're talking about potential career paths it's kind of a different story, I guess. But otherwise it's completely fine to have a low skill ceiling. It doesn't matter what anyone thinks of your output. I don't even show most of my stuff to other people, and I've been working on some of my music for years in private. Once I learned to be okay with doing it just for myself, a lot of my self doubts fell away.

I hope you'll keep trying, whatever it is.
parent.body_html:
I am at a high enough level to do that now, but my creative output has been pretty close to the same from my starting point up to now. Being stuck at a starting point has a way of forcing you to be creative, though, so I don't think even that is a bad thing.

If we're talking about potential career paths it's kind of a different story, I guess. But otherwise it's completely fine to have a low skill ceiling. It doesn't matter what anyone thinks of your output. I don't even show most of my stuff to other people, and I've been working on some of my music for years in private. Once I learned to be okay with doing it just for myself, a lot of my self doubts fell away.

I hope you'll keep trying, whatever it is.
